comments.commentBody:
"If they fail, we would get them into rehab and into the work force."

And who is going to get them into rehab and pay for that rehab? Name me one GOP politician who is willing to find the money to support drug rehab? Doesn't drug rehab go against the Ayn Rand philosophy of personal responsibility?

The GOP plan is likely to kick it back to the States, where Red states will do nothing but bus their drug addicts to Blue states.
Physically challenged.  As in unattractive, to be very polite.

This is the man who wants to only borrow money to pay for roads and his own party in Wisconsin has no idea how to repay the loans.  They want to raise their gas tax however the Gov. won't hear of it. Better to go bankrupt like Kansas than admit your policy is wrong.
Scott Walker's 'fight for taxpayers' means tax cuts for the donor class and dismantling public services and the social safety net.

Scott Walker is never at a loss for new ideas on how to deny people basic rights.  Let check Scott's subtext here:  Scott believes healthcare should be put in the hands of the individual states to ensure the GOP can finish off the ACA once and for all.
Don't forget deconstruction of the public sector. He's been doing that for 6 years too.

while I don't agree with the conservative agenda, I think Gov. Walker is correct that the R gov in DC should ignore the protests and enact their agenda. That way, the American voters will finally see who the Rs really care about and who they don't.

@stu freeman - the evidence is that Breitbart says so. Hey, Democrats were saying the only reason the Tea Party was protesting was because they were a Koch funded organization, why wouldn't the Republicans have similar rumors about the liberal protesters.

As for death threats, meh, when you're famous death threats are a dime a dozen, no matter what you stand for someone's going to hate it enough to send you death threats. That getting rid of the ACA is something only a small percentage of Americas actually want and that is potentially a life or death issue for many would tend to lead to more death threats. Hey, if Scott Walker is threatening to kill people by taking away their health care it's only natural they'd threaten to kill him in return.

"This is not just about touting Republican ideology...."

Of course, that is exactly what it is about, which is why Mr. Walker felt the need to insert this boilerplate denial language.

As far as voters sending a "clear answer" in 2016 when Mr. Trump lost the popular vote and won through an electoral college fluke, one has to wonder what sort of Republican fantasy world Mr. Walker has constructed for himself? Ideology, not reality, rules in the contemporary GOP.

Well there's an interesting position for me to find myself in, to be in  100% complete agreement with Richard Luettegen. As always, your answer is concise and well presented and well argued and this time I could not possibly agree with you more. In fact, I would buy you lunch if I knew you personally.

Why didn't the Republicans work with the Democrats to improve the ACA. It's not like they didn't have six years to do that. Problem is there is no good replacement for the ACA, unless we go to single payer, but even that would take quite awhile to implement and the Republicans would never go for in the first place.

Good thinking! Return all the power to the states, and while we're at it, let's restart slavery and all those other good things the government saw fit to interfere with, like prayer in public schools and women's right to choose. All these liberal agitators don't belong in this country--they belong in other countries like New York, California, and Oregon!
The hurtful anti-government philosophiy of Walker is almost too absurd to take seriously, especially when appearing in the most distinguished newspaper in the United States.  Underlline that United.

Except RL doesn't say exactly what the federal government should do about health care. His GOP buddies want to destroy Medicare, so it's unclear what RL means. He appears "reasonable," but so does Speaker Ryan, who wants to privatize God's green earth.
Scott walker is not a statesman and has no interest in middle class other than to take money from them to give to the 1%.  walker is a good liar as "liar in Chief" trump.
Government does what business neglects because the objective is not a matter of profit.

Health Care is a Human Right. A Universal Human Right. It is not something that should be left to the States.

In this area, the United States is not a leader, but a laggard. Civilized Nations provide for the welfare of their Citizens, rich or poor. So must the United States.

Try reading the Preamble to the United States Constitution, Mr. Walker, to get an idea of what the "Framers" had in mind. Then, change yours.
Another reason to avoid Wisconsin when deciding which college to attend- the race to the bottom mentality of Walker and his radical right wing surrogates.
We know how States use federal money that is not designated. Albany is an inspiration and a model for states rights.

It only took Scott Walker one sentence to get to a lie.  ..."after we made big promises on the campaign trail."  It's well known that Walker never disclosed his plans to dismantle the unions until after he was elected.  Had he spoken honestly of these plans while on the campaign trail, he never would have won.
The same thing happened with the "Right to Work" law on his re-election...

With all due respect, Mr. Walker, with several GOP-run states now trying to either restrict protesting or make it outright illegal, it seems that it is the protestors that need to remain strong against the likes of you.

As a Times subscriber and proud union member, I resent having to pay for Trumpian garbage like this. If I want to read the spewings of the execrable likes of the viciously anti-labor Scott Walker, there are plenty of conservative sites in which to wallow. I can only assume that the shaklily-liberal Times is, herein, grotesquely attempting to emulate the risibly bogus "fair and balanced" approach of Pravda, or Fox News as it's known in some circles. in future, please give me advance warning when you intend to do this: I will simply boycott the NYT site that day, lest I be afflicted by nausea and helpless rage.

"Listening to Walker" is the same as appeasement. You only have to read the second paragraph where he equates citizens exercising their first amendment rights with "intimidation."  You stand up against these people, period.

He's right about one thing.  Answer to your constituents--all of them.  We have a few who are MIA in the state when they come home from their "recesses" in Washington.  Too afraid of confronting their constituents, especially the ones who are seeking clarification or wanting to give input.

I really can't help but reply here, I'm not fully sure why. I lost my father just 2 months ago, perhaps that is my reason for a response. This is a love that only comes with acknowledging a loss. I only aknowledged a loss of the weak painful cancer ridden father, I did not think about the healthy full of life man I would lose. I hope she could reflect the opposite of her counterpart. Man, is life unpredictable. I hope the best for all that read this.
